image.altText: Police crouch over evidence behind crime scene tape.

items.synopsis: Detectives have identified a woman whose remains were located at a unit complex in Brisbane last year. The body of Tanya Lee Glover was found tightly wrapped, covered in bedding and hidden behind a brick wall.

title.children: Body found tightly wrapped and partially buried under Brisbane unit complex identified by police

image.altText: A security camera attached to the internal ceiling of a rental property.

items.synopsis: Sandy is facing the prospect of having nowhere to live after raising concerns about security cameras inside their rental property. She became so concerned she and her children left the property.

title.children: Queensland mother fears family were secretly filmed by cameras in their rental property

image.altText: A smiling woman with long, dark hair holds a shovel across her shoulder at a construction site. She wears a hard hat.

items.synopsis: Queensland Housing Minister Meaghan Scanlon says the government is aiming to maximise the use of space as the state continues to grapple with the housing shortage.

title.children: Minister tells critics to 'get out of the way' amid high-density housing push

image.altText: A close shot of Mr Butler's face, looking serious.

items.synopsis: The opposition will no longer attempt to unwind the government's scheme to halve the cost of hundreds of medications, asking instead for the government to take its act of "good faith" as a chance to redesign the scheme.

title.children: Coalition withdraws attempt to unwind half-price medication scheme, asking for government to delay start date

image.altText: Filipino marines standing on the deck of a rusty ship.

items.synopsis: For decades the Philippines have stationed a small contingent of marines on a rusting World War II warship that was deliberately run aground on a submerged reef in the South China Sea.

title.children: Why is China so keen to stop resupply ships reaching a dilapidated warship stuck on a South China Sea reef?

image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: Graphic of Australian Bank logos on houses including Commonwealth, ANZ, Westpac, and National.

items.synopsis: The big banks were offering cashback deals and competitive rates to grab their share of the refinancing boom, but the trend has reversed as margins start to come under pressure, leaving some borrowers trapped between a mortgage cliff and a mortgage prison.

title.children: Why the honeymoon is over — banks pull back on fight for new borrowers

image.altText: police tape down the side of a house

items.synopsis: Australian Defence Force personnel are travelling to Longreach to assess the object, found on a property once owned by late Queensland MP Vaughan Johnson.

title.children: Outback home under police guard after suspected World War II hand grenade found in yard

image.altText: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un fires a gun in a shooting range.

items.synopsis: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has dismissed the military's top general, called for a increased weapons production and an expansion of military drills, according to state media.

title.children: North Korea's Kim Jong Un dismisses top general, calls for war preparations

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: A COVID-19 variant nicknamed "Eris" — after the Greek goddess of chaos, strife and discord — has been in the news after spreading overseas. But the variant has actually been in Australia for four months.

title.children: The 'goddess of chaos' COVID variant is making headlines, but it’s been lurking quietly for months

image.altText: A female child star with a bob haircut, looks side-on to a camera with a vacant expression

items.synopsis: Lil Tay, whose real name is Claire Hope, made a name for herself by posting controversial but viral videos that involved a lot of profanity as well as designer clothes and luxury cars.

title.children: Child star Lil Tay, famed for controversial online videos, reportedly dies aged 14

image.altText: Actors.

items.synopsis: In India, the Modi government is accused of waging a war on Bollywood and using it for party propaganda.

title.children: 'You have to suck up or shut up': The clampdown on Bollywood's unforgivable sin

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: Australians with mental health issues are the fastest-growing group needing specialist homelessness services, according to a federal government report. Here, a Queensland woman reveals how she has come to be among them.

title.children: Being abused as a child left Phoebe Staggard with ongoing trauma. It has also left her homeless

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: About 30 per cent of Australians live in rental accommodation with growing numbers in seats that helped secure government for Labor. But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week is looming as an important moment for Australian housing

image.altText: A French World Cup player looks to her left during a match.

items.synopsis: France defender Ève Périsset is set to mark Caitlin Foord in Saturday's Women's World Cup quarterfinal, while helping  her teammates plot how they will handle Chelsea colleague Sam Kerr.

title.children: The French star with the tips on how to handle Foord, Kerr in World Cup clash against Matildas

image.altText: signs for a level crossing

items.synopsis: A level crossing north of Brisbane has taken the top spot for delaying traffic during the morning commute, with the boom gates blocking motorists for an average of about 90 minutes each weekday morning.

title.children: Government lists the worst 13 level crossings for holding up traffic in south-east Queensland

image.altText: An Australian para-cyclist is congratulated after winning gold at the world championships.

items.synopsis: Just over a year out from the Paris Paralympic Games, Australia's Lauren Parker becomes a world champion in a second sport, striking hand-cycling gold after shining in the para-triathlon over recent years.

title.children: Aussie Parker wins world para-cycling title as Paralympics loom on the horizon

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander agencies, Voice to Parliament advocates and the prime minister have described a conspiracy theory on the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart as a misinformation campaign to avoid debating the facts.

title.children: Voice to Parliament conspiracy theory an attempt to create 'misinformation and division'

image.altText: A stylised graphic of the ASX board with an up arrow.

items.synopsis: Wall Street indices fall overnight but the Australian share market looks set to buck the trend and rise in early trade.

title.children: Wall Street falls, Australian market set to defy downward lead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More evidence that, after a year of relative resilience to higher interest rates, the Australian consumer has finally given up the ghost. ANZ monitors the spending made through its cards and merchant payment facilities (i.e. point-of-sale terminals) to get a near-real time pulse on consumer spending. There isn't much of one. Over the week to August 5, spending dived 8% compared with the same period a year earlier. Considering how much prices have risen for most things over that year, that is a huge fall in the volume of goods and services being purchased. As you can see, Aussies cut spending on almost everything, even staples like groceries. The only sector going up was entertainment, driven by a 95% jump in cinema spending as the Barbie movie and Oppenheimer opened at the same time, the so-called "Barbenheimer" effect. We're not even going out for meals or drinks anymore, with dining-out spending now below pre-pandemic levels in 2019. "The ongoing softness in ANZ-observed spending, alongside the weak ABS household spending indicator and negative retail volumes print, suggests the RBA's efforts to curb spending are working," note ANZ economists Madeline Dunk and Adelaide Timbrell. "Many households are facing a cashflow squeeze and are adjusting by curbing spending."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Barbenheimer sends Aussies to the cinema, but spending plunges elsewhere

children.content: More evidence that, after a year of relative resilience to higher interest rates, the Australian consumer has finally given up the ghost.
ANZ monitors the spending made through its cards and merchant payment facilities (i.e. point-of-sale terminals) to get a near-real time pulse on consumer spending.
There isn't much of one.
Over the week to August 5, spending dived 8% compared with the same period a year earlier.
Considering how much prices have risen for most things over that year, that is a huge fall in the volume of goods and services being purchased.

props.alt: Internal ANZ data reveals what Australians are cutting back on

children.content: Internal ANZ data reveals what Australians are cutting back on
(ANZ)
As you can see, Aussies cut spending on almost everything, even staples like groceries.
The only sector going up was entertainment, driven by a 95% jump in cinema spending as the Barbie movie and Oppenheimer opened at the same time, the so-called "Barbenheimer" effect.

props.alt: Australians cut spending in most areas of life at the start of this month

children.content: Australians cut spending in most areas of life at the start of this month
(ANZ)
We're not even going out for meals or drinks anymore, with dining-out spending now below pre-pandemic levels in 2019.

props.alt: Restaurants are seeing less diners through their doors

children.content: Restaurants are seeing less diners through their doors since April
(ANZ/Open Table)

"The ongoing softness in ANZ-observed spending, alongside the weak ABS household spending indicator and negative retail volumes print, suggests the RBA's efforts to curb spending are working," note ANZ economists Madeline Dunk and Adelaide Timbrell.
"Many households are facing a cashflow squeeze and are adjusting by curbing spending."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: QBE Insurance announced its half-year profit result this morning. It made US$400 million ( $612 million in Australian dollars ) net profit after income tax for the half year ended 30 June, up from $US48 million for the prior period, an increase of 733%. It will pay a dividend of 14 cents (Australian) per share. That's higher than the previous corresponding period's 9 cents. Its share price has lost 2.5% in value this morning, down 39 cents to $15.21. QBE has lifted its group-wide premiums to offset an increase in claims, like its rival Suncorp. The global insurer operates in more than two dozen countries, and its group-wide premium rate increases averaged 10.2% in the first half of this year, compared with 8.1% in prior period. The net cost of its catastrophe claims increased to $US699 million, or 8.7% of net insurance revenue, compared to 6.2% in the prior period. Its catastrophe costs were underscored by the historically bad weather events in New Zealand in February (damaging flooding and Cyclone Gabrielle) and material convective storm activity in North America. Here's how QBE's premium increases look by region: North America: +10.9% International: +9.4% Australia Pacific: +11.8% Also like Suncorp, QBE's final profit result was achieved with help from large investment returns. Total investment income for the period was $US662 million, compared with a loss of $US20 million for the prior period. It says those investment returns reflect the significant increase in interest rates over the period and a gain of $US52 million from tighter credit spreads.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: QBE Insurance posts $612 million half-year profit, lifts premiums

children.content: QBE Insurance announced its half-year profit result this morning.
It made US$400 million (
$612 million in Australian dollars
) net profit after income tax for the half year ended 30 June, up from $US48 million for the prior period, an
increase of 733%
It will pay a dividend of 14 cents (Australian) per share. That's higher than the previous corresponding period's 9 cents.
Its
share price
has lost 2.5%
in value this morning,
down 39 cents
to
QBE has lifted its group-wide premiums to offset an increase in claims, like its rival Suncorp.
The global insurer operates in more than two dozen countries, and its group-wide
premium rate increases averaged 10.2%
in the first half of this year, compared with 8.1% in prior period.
The net cost of its catastrophe claims increased to $US699 million, or 8.7% of net insurance revenue, compared to 6.2% in the prior period.

Its catastrophe costs were underscored by the historically bad weather events in New Zealand in February (damaging flooding and Cyclone Gabrielle) and material convective storm activity in North America.
Here's how QBE's premium increases look by region:
North America: +10.9%
International: +9.4%
Australia Pacific: +11.8%
Also like Suncorp, QBE's final profit result was achieved with help from large investment returns.
Total investment income for the period was $US662 million, compared with a loss of $US20 million for the prior period.
It says those investment returns reflect the significant increase in interest rates over the period and a gain of $US52 million from tighter credit spreads.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AMP has posted a 44% drop in net profit to $261 million for the half-year ended on June 30, 2023. Its result was boosted by a $209 million gain on the sale of its international infrastructure equity business, while the previous year's first-half result was even more inflated by the sale of its real estate and domestic infrastructure business. Looking at only the businesses that AMP continues to operate, net profit came in at $52 million, down 45% from the previous first-half result. AMP said its underlying profit results were roughly in line with the first-half last year at $112 million. The company said its banking division saw a 24% rise in profit, while its investment platform saw underlying profits up nearly 26%. Its advice business posted a $25 million underlying loss, although AMP said this was smaller than last year. "We have significantly reduced the size and complexity of AMP's business, whilst continuing to resolve legacy issues," said the financial firm's CEO Alexis George. "We have outlined a target to deliver $120 million in run rate controllable cost savings by FY 25, with a $60 million reduction in FY 24 and a similar number for FY 25. "This will be achieved through simplifying our technology architecture, removing stranded costs, reducing group costs including property, continued focus on the Advice business, replatforming our Master Trust business and a disciplined approach to project spend." Between divestments and cost-cutting, AMP is striving to shrink its way back to greatness.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AMP profits drop as company deals with 'legacy issues'

children.content: AMP has posted a 44% drop in net profit to $261 million
for the half-year ended on June 30, 2023.
Its result was boosted by
a $209 million gain on the sale of its international infrastructure equity business
, while the previous year's first-half result was even more inflated by the sale of its real estate and domestic infrastructure business.
Looking at only the businesses that AMP continues to operate,
net profit came in at $52 million, down 45%
from the previous first-half result.
AMP said its
underlying profit results
were roughly in line with the first-half last year at
$112 million
The company said its
banking division saw a 24% rise in profit
, while its
investment platform saw underlying profits up nearly 26%
Its
advice business posted a $25 million underlying loss
, although AMP said this was smaller than last year.
"We have significantly reduced the size and complexity of AMP's business, whilst continuing to resolve legacy issues," said the financial firm's CEO Alexis George.
"We have outlined a target to deliver $120 million in run rate controllable cost savings by FY 25, with a $60 million reduction in FY 24 and a similar number for FY 25.

"This will be achieved through simplifying our technology architecture, removing stranded costs, reducing group costs including property, continued focus on the Advice business, replatforming our Master Trust business and a disciplined approach to project spend."
Between divestments and cost-cutting, AMP is striving to shrink its way back to greatness.

image.altText: A man sits on the edge of a swimming pool wearing a yellow lifeguard shirt and red hat.

items.synopsis: Royal Life Saving Society Queensland says regional areas struggle to find aquatic centre staff, as worker shortages impact the industry.

title.children: When Michael's pool closed due to lifeguard shortages last summer, he decided to act

image.altText: A man in a black shirt and scar, arrives at a premiere, smiling to photographers

items.synopsis: The Canadian-born Robertson was a high school dropout who fell in love with the seemingly limitless sounds and byways of his adopted US.

title.children: Robbie Robertson, lead guitarist and songwriter of The Band, dies at 80

image.altText: Two older women with stick horses in the hands smile at the camera,  with a cityscape visible behind them.

items.synopsis: The quirky sport, which involves participants straddling stick horses and simulating events such as show jumping and dressage, is gaining popularity in south-east Queensland.

title.children: These Australians are happy to get on their hobby horses — and they're keen for others to do the same

image.altText: Flags of China and U.S. are displayed on a printed circuit board with semiconductor chips.

items.synopsis: The US president signs an executive order to narrowly prohibit certain US investments in sensitive technology in China and require government notification of funding in other tech sectors.

title.children: Biden signs order to ban certain tech investments in China

image.altText: A man with shaved head and work shirt smiles down at camera above pile of rubbish.

items.synopsis: Bush access is being restricted in hotspots where volunteers are removing white goods, used nappies, and burnt-out cars illegally dumped in Queensland bushland.

title.children: Phil has collected 75 tonnes of rubbish dumped in the bush and says the solution is a 'sad' reality

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses and a red jacket

items.synopsis: Legislation to establish the Parliamentary Workplace Support Service is the first major tranche of legislation to deal with the recommendations made by former Sex Discrimination Commissioner.

title.children: Legislation to establish parliament human resources agency tabled two years after sexual harassment review

image.altText: Wild Mushroom Death Cap

items.synopsis: The deaths of three Victorians after a Saturday lunch in the small town of Leongatha sent shock waves through the community, but also shone the spotlight on one of the most poisonous organisms on earth.

title.children: What happens when you eat a death cap mushroom?

image.altText: A big slab of rock with a bone fossil of an ancient giant amphibian inside

items.synopsis: Almost 30 years after a chicken farmer found an almost perfectly preserved fossil in a slab of sandstone, scientists have identified the skeleton as a prehistoric amphibian.

title.children: 'An incredibly rare find': This ancient amphibian almost ended up forgotten inside a sandstone slab wall

items.synopsis: Ewing's world title hopes appear over after the Australian fractures his back while surfing Teahupo'o ahead of the Tahiti Pro.

title.children: Aussie surfer Ethan Ewing breaks back, WSL finals tilt in doubt
